title: Paramedics suffering ‘epidemic’ and ‘intolerable’ levels of stress
text:
Workers such as paramedics are suffering from ‘epidemic’ levels of stress (Picture: Getty)

One in three ambulance workers have been diagnosed with a mental health problem, a new survey suggests.

Workers such as paramedics are suffering from ‘epidemic’ levels of stress, amid unrealistic targets and excessive workloads, according to the study.

A survey of 550 members of the Unite union found that over half suffered from anxiety, while many reported feeling depressed, irritable, or feeling traumatised by their work.

The report, published on World Mental Health Day, said many ambulance staff complained of late finishes and a lack of flexible working.

A third of those polled said they had been diagnosed with a mental health problem, with many taking time off sick as a result.

Unite official Debbie Wilkinson said: ‘The fact that frontline ambulance staff who save lives on a daily basis are suffering such serious levels of stress and mental ill health is both intolerable and unsustainable. It is time for us to care for the carer.’

The British Safety Council urged the Government and businesses to invest in workplace well-being. (Picture: Getty)

Another study indicated a sharp increase in the number of young women worried about their mental health, partly because of sexism and money worries.

The Young Women’s Trust said its survey of 2,000 young women found that two-thirds saw sexism as a major problem, which impacted on their mental health.

‘What too often is dismissed as young women lacking confidence is in fact a crisis in young women’s mental health caused by a sexist society,” Young Women’s Trust chief executive Sophie Walker said.

‘It is deeply affecting their lives and their economic freedom.’

Research by Ipsos MORI for Teladoc Health indicated that four out of five people in the UK with a mental health condition did not confide in their managers.

Two out of five of the 1,000 adults questioned said they gave a false reason for mental health-related time off.

The British Safety Council urged the Government and businesses to invest in workplace well-being.

Chairman Lawrence Waterman said three out of five people have experienced mental health issues due to work.

‘Changes that reduce stress, encourage early intervention and remove the mental health stigma, deliver significant long-term benefits,’ he added.
